# Purpose{.unnumbered}
In 2018, the average US adult spent just under three hours on a smart phone per day. This number has been increasing each year. With this large prevalence of smart phone technology on society, distracted driving is seemingly on the rise. Distracted driving due to smart phones can be categorized as texting, calling, internet surfing, or any other activity on the phone while driving. The purpose of this analysis is to use descriptive and inferential statistics to describe, calculate, and illustrate our findings of if the emergence of smart phone technology relates to the rate of distracted driving accidents.
